questions.text: Edematous villi with chromosome XY was found. What will be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A complete molar pregnancy is diploid (46,XX or 46,XY) and results from the fertilization of an empty ovum by either a single sperm that duplicates or by two sperms. Histopathological examination reveals diffusely edematous (swollen) villi with excessive trophoblastic proliferation and a complete absence of fetal tissue.

 

Feature

Partial Mole

Complete Mole

Karyotype

Usually 69, XXY or 69, XXX (triploid) (Option B ruled out)

Usually 46, XX or 46, XY (diploid)

Genetic origin

2 paternal sets + 1 maternal set

All paternal (empty egg + sperm duplication)

Fetal tissue

It may be present but abnormal.

Absent.

β-hCG levels

Elevated, but lower than the complete mole

Very high

Risk of persistent GTD

5-10%

15-20%

Risk of choriocarcinoma

2-4%

2-3%

Theca lutein cysts

Less common

Common

HPE findings
  • Focal villous edema (some villi are normal, others are edematous)
  • Presence of fetal blood vessels in some villi.
  • Focal trophoblastic hyperplasia
  • Presence of fetal tissue (may include fetal red blood cells or embryonic/fetal parts).
  • Diffuse villous edema and hydropic swelling.
  • Absence of fetal blood vessels in villi
  • Marked atypical trophoblastic hyperplasia (both cytotrophoblast and syncytiotrophoblast).
  • No fetal tissue is present.

 

 

A cyst (Option C) may develop in the ovaries or placenta during pregnancy but does not exhibit edematous villi or chromosomal abnormalities like a molar pregnancy.


An ectopic pregnancy (Option D) occurs outside the uterus, does not exhibit molar villi, and lacks the characteristic hydropic changes seen in molar pregnancies.

questions.text:
A pregnant woman presented with complaints of passing grape-like vesicles vaginally. A USG scan was done and is shown below. Which of the following hormone levels need to be checked in this patient?

hCG-Human Chorionic Gonadotropin
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) hCG

Explanation:

  • The presentation of grape-like vesicles and the ultrasound finding showing a snowstorm appearance strongly suggest a hydatidiform mole. The most appropriate hormone level to check in this patient is hCG (Human Chorionic Gonadotropin).

Follow-up of Molar Pregnancy:

  • β-hCG Monitoring:
    • The initial test is within 48 hours post-evacuation for baseline.
    • Follow-up every 1-2 weeks until 3 consecutive normal values
    • Post-Normalization Testing: Monthly β-hCG tests for another 6 months.
  • Median Resolution Time for GTD :
    • Partial moles: 6 weeks.
    • Complete moles: 7 weeks.
  • Normalisation Timeline of beta HCG levels:
    • 95% by 14 weeks.
    • 99% by 25 weeks
  • Evaluation for gestational trophoblastic neoplasia is required if β-hCG levels increase or plateau.

  • It is advised to avoid conception for up to 12 months. But If Pregnancy is desired, may conceive 6 months after serum beta HCG normalization.
  • Delay pregnancy for 1 year after gestational trophoblastic neoplasia and 2 years if metastasis is present.

questions.text: A woman who underwent dilatation and curettage for molar pregnancy six months ago presents with persistent abdominal pain and distention symptoms. On further evaluation, the beta-hCG levels were persistently elevated, and cannonball foci were found on the chest X-ray. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Gestational trophoblastic disease

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestations indicate gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD), specifically its malignant form called gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN).
  • This diagnosis is supported by the history of molar pregnancy, persistently elevated beta-hCG levels, and characteristic "cannonball" metastases on chest X-ray.
  • GTN represents the malignant spectrum of GTD that can develop after a molar pregnancy.
  • The disease is characterized by abnormal trophoblastic proliferation with the potential for local invasion and distant metastasis, particularly to the lungs where they appear as multiple, well-circumscribed "cannonball" lesions on chest imaging.

Gestational Trophoblastic Disease

Definition and Classification
  • Hydatidiform Moles (HM):
    • Complete Mole: No fetal parts, abnormal placental development
    • Partial Mole: Some fetal parts present, abnormal placental tissue
  • Gestational Trophoblastic Neoplasia (GTN):
    • Invasive Mole: Deep penetration into uterine wall
    • Choriocarcinoma: Aggressive malignant form
    • Epithelioid Trophoblastic Tumor (ETT): Rare variant
    • Placental Site Trophoblastic Tumor (PSTT): Originating from implantation site

Risk Factors
  • Risk Factors:
    • Maternal age >35 or <21 years
    • Previous molar pregnancy (1% recurrence risk)
    • Asian ethnicity
    • History of spontaneous abortion
    • Dietary deficiencies (vitamin A, animal fats)
    • Blood type A

Pathogenesis and Genetics
  • Complete Mole:
    • 46,XX (90%) - all paternal chromosomes
    • 46,XY (10%) - all paternal chromosomes
    • Empty egg fertilized by sperm that duplicates
    • Maternal mitochondrial DNA present
  • Partial Mole:
    • Triploid: 69,XXX, 69,XXY, or 69,XYY
    • Fertilization by two sperm
    • Contains both maternal and paternal DNA
  • Molecular Features:
    • p53 and MDM2 overexpression
    • HLA-G expression in choriocarcinoma
    • Altered NECC1 and growth factor expression

Clinical Presentation
  • First Trimester:
    • Vaginal bleeding (84% of cases)
    • Dark brown/prune juice-like discharge
    • Passage of grape-like vesicles
    • Hyperemesis gravidarum
  • Later Presentation:
    • Hyperthyroidism symptoms
    • Early pre-eclampsia (<20 weeks)
    • Respiratory distress
    • Theca lutein cysts
  • Physical Findings:
    • Uterine size-date discrepancy
    • Absent fetal heart tones (complete mole)
    • Adnexal masses

Diagnostic Evaluation
  • Imaging Studies:
    • Ultrasound: "Snowstorm" or "grape-like" pattern
    • Chest X-ray for metastasis (Cannonball foci in lungs)
    • ​​​​​​​
    • CT/PET for staging
    • MRI for atypical presentations
  • Laboratory Tests:
    • Quantitative β-hCG levels
    • Complete blood count
    • Coagulation studies
    • Liver and renal function
    • Thyroid function tests
  • Histopathological Features:
    • Complete Mole: Diffuse villous edema, trophoblastic hyperplasia
    • Partial Mole: Mixed normal and hydropic villi
    • Choriocarcinoma: Biphasic pattern with hemorrhage

Incorrect Options:

Endometriosis (Option B): Endometriosis typically presents with cyclic pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea, and infertility. It would not explain the elevated β-hCG levels or pulmonary lesions. Endometriosis doesn't cause elevated beta-hCG or lung metastases

Ovarian cyst (Option C): Ovarian cyst can cause abdominal pain and distention, but it would not explain persistently elevated β-hCG levels or pulmonary metastases.

Asherman's syndrome (Option D): Asherman's syndrome is characterized by intrauterine adhesions following D&C, causing amenorrhea and infertility. It would not cause elevated β-hCG or pulmonary lesions.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female primigravida with a history of 3 months of amenorrhoea undergoes USG. The USG done is shown below. What is the USG suggestive of?

choices.text: Multiple renal cysts in the fetus

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hydatidiform mole

Explanation:

  • The ultrasound findings include a heterogeneous mass in the uterine cavity with multiple anechoic spaces, most commonly referred to as a "snowstorm" appearance which indicates a complete molar pregnancy.
  • Typically, USG findings of molar pregnancy reveal a distended endometrial cavity containing a heterogeneous intrauterine mass with multiple cystic spaces demonstrating a snowstorm appearance with absent fetal parts.

 

Ectopic pregnancy (Option A): Ectopic pregnancy refers to the implantation of the fertilized egg outside of the uterus, typically in the fallopian tubes. USG findings would show an empty uterine cavity with or without an adnexal mass or free fluid in the pelvis. The described findings do not suggest ectopic pregnancy.

Multiple renal cysts in the fetus (Option C): This option refers to the presence of cysts in the fetal kidneys. However, the scenario does not mention any fetal renal abnormalities, and the focus is on the patient's amenorrhea and the ultrasound findings related to the pregnancy.

Oligohydramnios (Option D): Oligohydramnios refers to a reduced amount of amniotic fluid surrounding the fetus. While it is possible to evaluate amniotic fluid levels using ultrasound, the given scenario does not mention any findings related to amniotic fluid levels or fetal well-being.

questions.text: Serial monitoring of serum beta hCG is required for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Molar pregnancy

Explanation:

Hydatidiform mole or molar pregnancy is classified as a benign form of GTD and is characterized by abnormal growth of trophoblastic tissue in the uterus. This results in swollen, fluid-filled villi and significantly elevated β-hCG levels (often in the range of 100,000 mIU/mL or higher). Though initially benign, they can sometimes progress to persistent gestational trophoblastic disease or malignancy.

Downs syndrome (Option A): Downs syndrome is diagnosed through prenatal screening and NIPT.

Pregnancy-associated with Neural tube defects (Option B): Neural tube defects are detected through ultrasound and genetic testing.

Rh-negative pregnancy (Option D): Rh-negative pregnancy doesn't require routine hCG monitoring.

questions.text: A primigravida in her 10th week of gestation presents with spotting. On examination, the uterus corresponds to 12 weeks. Transvaginal ultrasound was done and it is given below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Hydatidiform mole

Explanation: Primigravida with spotting and a "snowstorm" appearance on ultrasound points towards a diagnosis of hydatidiform mole.

Hydatidiform mole:

  • Benign form of the gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD).
  • Characterized by abnormal trophoblastic tissue growth in the uterus, leading to swollen, fluid-filled villi and markedly elevated β-hCG levels, often exceeding 100,000 mIU/mL.
  • While initially benign, it can occasionally progress to persistent gestational trophoblastic disease or malignancy.
  • Clinical Findings:
    • Amenorrhea
    • Uterine Bleeding (Most common feature)
    • Uterine Growth: Larger than expected for gestational age and softer in texture.
    • Absence of Fetal Heart Sounds: Complete moles show no fetal heart motion.
    • Theca-Lutein Cysts: Ovaries may show cysts >6 cm.
    • Hyperthyroidism
    • Severe Preeclampsia/Eclampsia
    • Lower abdominal pain
    • Hyperemesis gravidarum
  • Diagnosis:
    • Serum β-hCG > 1,00,000 mIU/ml
    • Ultrasonography: Complete mole appears as an echogenic uterine mass with anechoic cystic spaces, resembling a "snowstorm" appearance, with no visible fetus or amniotic sac.
  • Management:
    • Suction and evacuation after cervical preparation.
    • Follow-up: Serial hCG monitoring.
    • Prophylactic chemotherapy: Administer methotrexate (1 mg/kg/day) on days 1, 3, 5, and 7 for high-risk women (WHO score >7).
    • Avoid pregnancy for at least one year.

Blighted ovum (Option A) is an anembryonic gestation where the fertilized egg implants in the uterus, but no embryo develops. On ultrasound, it shows a gestational sac without a fetal pole.

Missed abortion (Option B): In this condition, the fetus dies but remains in the uterus, causing no immediate symptoms. Ultrasound reveals an empty sac or absence of fetal cardiac activity and movement in an early pregnancy.

Ectopic pregnancy (Option C) is a life-threatening condition where the fertilized egg implants outside the uterine cavity, usually in the fallopian tube, and requires immediate intervention. Ultrasound shows no intrauterine pregnancy.

questions.text: What is the appropriate management for a 35-year-old woman with choriocarcinoma who presents with metastases to lung spleen and kidney, had a previous molar pregnancy removed 6 months ago, a pretreatment serum hCG level of 10,000IU/ml, a tumor of 6 cm diameter in the uterus, and failed chemotherapy with methotrexate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) EMACO regimen

Explanation: The patient has stage IV disease (mets to organs other than lungs) with a score of 11 on the WHO prognostic system. Stage 4 (FIGO) is a criterion by itself for the EMACO regimen. Stage 4 or stages 2 and 3 with a risk score > 6 are criteria for High-risk invasive mole and choriocarcinoma.

Modified WHO Prognostic Scoring System as Adapted by FIGO

Scores

0

1

2

4

Age (years)

<40

≥40

-

-

Antecedent pregnancy

Mole

Abortion

Term

-

Interval months from index pregnancy

<4

4-6

7-12

>12

Pretreatment serum β-hCG (mIU/mL)

<10³

10³-<10⁴

10⁴-<10⁵

≥10⁵

Largest tumor size (including uterus)

<3 cm

3-4 cm

≥5 cm

-

Site of metastases

Spleen, kidney

GIT

Liver, brain

-

Number of metastases

1-4

5-8

>8

-

Previous failed chemotherapy drugs

-

1

≥2

-

Low risk = WHO score of 0 to 6.

High risk = WHO score of ≥7.

Management

  • ≤ 6 Score: Single Agent: Methotrexate with alternate day folinic acid
  • ≥ 7 Score: EMACO Regimen (preferred regimen)
  • Etoposide
  • Methotrexate
  • Actinomycin D
  • Cyclophosphamide
  • Oncovin

Methotrexate with folinic acid (Option A) is generally given for low-risk GTN and not high-risk GTN with metastasis.

Methotrexate (Option B) alone is not the most appropriate choice in this case. Methotrexate is typically used in combination with folinic acid to maximize its efficacy while minimizing toxicity in low-risk GTN and not high-risk GTN with metastasis.

Hysterectomy (Option D) involves the surgical removal of the uterus. In cases of gestational trophoblastic neoplasia, hysterectomy may be considered as a definitive treatment option if the disease is localized and the patient has completed childbearing.

questions.text: A patient with 12 weeks of amenorrhea presents with vaginal bleeding. On examination, the cervix is favorable. USG shows a snowstorm appearance. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Suction and evacuation

Explanation:

The clinical presentation with vaginal bleeding, a favorable cervix and the ultrasound findings of a snowstorm appearance are highly suggestive of a complete or partial molar pregnancy.

  • The patient comes under Group A, where the cervix is favorable. The recommended management includes suction and evacuation.
  • A negative pressure of 200–250 mm Hg is applied during the procedure, which is usually performed under diazepam sedation or general anesthesia.

The next best step in management for this condition is suction and evacuation (also known as dilatation and curettage) to remove the abnormal trophoblastic tissue.

 

Medical management (Option A) is not appropriate in the case of a molar pregnancy. Molar pregnancies require the complete removal of the abnormal tissue.

While beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (beta-HCG) levels (Option B) are used to monitor the response to treatment in molar pregnancies, the immediate management in this scenario is to evacuate the uterus due to the risk of complications associated with molar pregnancies.

Hysterectomy (Option D) is not the initial management for a molar pregnancy. Conservative management with suction and evacuation is the preferred approach unless there are specific indications for hysterectomy.

questions.text: The USG given below is seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Hydatidiform mole

Explanation:

  • The USG image showing a "snowstorm appearance" is characteristic of a hydatidiform mole, which is a form of gestational trophoblastic disease. This appearance is due to the presence of multiple cystic spaces within the uterus, representing swollen villi of the placenta. In hydatidiform mole, there is a failure of the embryo to develop, leading to abnormal growth of the placental tissue.
  • Hydatidiform mole is classified as a benign form of GTD and is characterized by abnormal growth of trophoblastic tissue in the uterus. This results in swollen, fluid-filled villi and significantly elevated β-hCG levels (often in the range of 100,000 mIU/mL or higher).
  • Initially benign, they can sometimes progress to persistent gestational trophoblastic disease or malignancy.

Molar Pregnancy (Benign)

Gestational Trophoblastic Neoplasia (Malignant)
  • Partial Mole
  • Complete Mole
  • Invasive Mole
  • Choriocarcinoma
  • Placental Site Trophoblastic Tumor (PSTT)
  • Epithelial Trophoblastic Tumor (ETT)

Complete Mole and Partial Mole:

Feature

Complete Mole

Partial Mole

Karyotype

46 XX or 46 XY

69 XYY or 69 XXY (triploid)

Diagnosis

Molar pregnancy

Missed abortion

Genetic Origin

All paternal (empty egg + sperm duplication)

2 paternal sets + 1 maternal set

Fetal Tissue

Absent

May be present but abnormal

β-hCG Levels

Extremely high (>1,00,000 mIU/mL)

Elevated, but lower than complete mole

Risk of Persistent GTD

15-20%

5-10%

Risk of Choriocarcinoma

2-3%

2-4%

Theca Lutein Cysts

Common (25-30% of cases)

Less common

Uterus Size

Larger than expected for gestational age

Smaller than expected for gestational age

Vaginal Bleeding

Common (80-90%), dark and intermittent

Less prominent, often associated with missed abortion

Hyperemesis Gravidarum

Common due to high hCG levels

Less common

Hyperthyroidism

Possible due to hCG/TSH similarity

Rare

Products of Conception

Complete molar tissue (grape-like vesicles)

Less advanced hydatidiform changes

Villous Edema

Diffuse, widespread

Focal

Trophoblastic Proliferation

Marked atypical trophoblastic hyperplasia

Focal to mild

Trophoblast Atypia

Prominent

Mild

p57KIP2 Immunostaining

Negative

Positive

In ectopic pregnancy (Option A), the classical USG finding is a "ring of fire" appearance, which is seen due to the vascularization of the ectopic mass. The snowstorm appearance is not typical for ectopic pregnancy.

Ovarian pregnancy (Option B) is a rare type of ectopic pregnancy where the embryo implants in the ovary. It can be difficult to diagnose on ultrasound, but it is typically associated with a mass in the ovary rather than a snowstorm appearance.

Anencephaly (Option C) is characterized by the absence of the brain and skull, and the classic ultrasound finding is the "frog eye sign," where the eyes appear to protrude abnormally due to the absence of the cranial vault. This is not the finding described in the question, which is indicative of hydatidiform mole.
